pageContent.description: mining mechanic + stability system creating the core gameplay loop
desinging our underground

content: After we got the first prototype up and running, we sat down to design our base underground.
To 'prototype' the layout, we used miro's sticky notes.
Of course tile based games taking place undergrounds already existed but that made it even more important for us to figure out what the best way was for our game.
The following points were in fokus:
tile size - How big is one tile compared to the player?
Rocks - Which directions should the rocks block, should they spawn in layers, or which rules should their placement follow?
Caves  - What do the caves need to feel/look like to fulfill the mining fantasy?
Riches - In which form do riches spawn? Do they (only) spawn close to rocks?
Tools - which tools can the player use to move vertically? What are alternatives to the ladder?
To fulfill the mining fantasy, we started designing the stability system.
From our players we anticipated the behavior of digging a straight tunnel. With this expectation in mind, we began to define some rules:
Tunnels that are not supported should crumble.
The crumbling should be forshadowed and not immediate, to give the player time to understand and react.
The crumbling tiles should then fall down and pose a hazard to the player.
Crumbling should leave cave-like shapes that are stable. No endless chain reactions.
The crumbling should leave cave-like shapes that are stable. No endless chain-reactions.
Once we had the rules we wanted, we tried a number-based system where the stability of each tile depends on the surrounding tiles.
Tiles with low stability start to crumble and fall off.
The stability system was eventually revised and improved several times to ensure the desired experience in all situations.

pageContent.description: designing the stability system
the tunnel & mine shapes of different playtests

content: To evaluate the changes and understand whether our systems were generating the right experiences, we conducted regular playtests.
The shapes that players dug up told us a lot about the actual dynamics of our system.
The resulting shapes helped us identify and eliminate dominant strategies at the outset, as well as the parameters of world generation.
This turned out to be a great indicator of short- and long-term motivations and goals, and was critical for balancing the placement of narrative content.
After taking care of the core gameplay, we carefully added layers of features and content on top.
Instead of taking paths that have been proven in other games, we focused on making sure these layers supported the fantasy of being a miner.
Since time was very limited for our bachelor project, we used the last few weeks to add content that used the systems and mechanics we had developed in the weeks before.
We created different themed areas with their own visual style, unique objects and little stories.
The areas were layered vertically from the surface further and further down.
The further down the levels are, the later players will reach them.
Even though the game was not linear, the levels and their content were the essential building blocks that helped us build the narrative and mechanical progression.
Each level fulfilled a different role in this by both teaching and challenging the player.
With this structure in hand, we suddenly had a lot more control without losing the open-ended and exploratory nature that core loops need.
The narrative is about the idea of digging deeper and deeper underground, about the self-conviction that what we do is important, and about the lies we tell ourselves and others because of it.
For me, the project is an opportunity for self-reflection both on our own actions and on my view of game design and development in general.

irina.name: Irina 28-07-37
description: A young female soldier wakes up without memory on a battlefield among robot parts and human corpses.
Wounded and alone, she scours the military base in search of other survivors. But what she finds makes her doubt everything she thought she knew.

content: A young female soldier wakes up without memory on a battlefield among robot parts and human corpses.
Wounded and alone, she scours the military base in search of other survivors.
But what she finds makes her doubt everything she thought she knew.
Co-Director
Co-Author
Visual Effects
The idea for Irina came with the insane plan to make a science fiction film on a low budget.
The image of a woman staring stunned at robot parts in her own arm was the starting point for a story that would be about the question of humanity.
The film deals with being different, and uses the distinction between humans and robots as an example for all the various forms of exclusion and racism.
We were aware that a science fiction film has to convince in two elements in particular: the production design and the visual effect.
We had rented a bunker that is normally used as a venue for festivities.
Emptying the bunker was one thing, but making it look convincingly like a military base was quite another.
We needed robots, furnishings, practicals, hoses, cables, etc.
In post-production, the visual effects became our biggest challenge.
While effects like the fire or the electric flash worked quickly, the robot arm of our protagonist turned out to be tricky.
In the end, I had to spend a considerable amount of time learning more complex tracking methods, software and compositing techniques.
It turned out as quite a valuable learning experience.
In the end, the daring project only worked thanks to a great team that contributed all the important things that breathe life into the story during our long day of shooting.
Despite all the challenges, mistakes and misjudgments and misjudgments, we are proud of our film, which has nothing to hide, especially on the big screen. Especially on the big screen.
Not only did it allow us to try out one of our favorite genres, but we'll take our experience with us into all future projects, no matter how big or small or how difficult to realize they may seem.

pageContent.description: the start of the game at vers. 0.5

content: In addition to coordinative and conceptual work, I was very interested in being hands-on in the Unreal engine.

I had the opportunity to do level design at various stages. Early on, I went from concept to blockout, using sightlines and forshadowing to create an initial tutorial section. Then later in designing the level surrounding some of my puzzles.
Adding the light puzzles came as a late solution to diversify the gameplay and give the player a reason to move through the space.

pageContent.description: blockout and asset version of the tutorial
demo level for the light puzzle mechanics

content: I used the designs to create a playable demo for the new mechanic within a day, to show the team how this mechanic could help tie up loose ends.
By improving player feedback for the lighting system, I was able to incorporate some time shaders and sounds that I really enjoyed.
I designed puzzles for each island and a final one that unlocks the ending, which includes a final puzzle that leads to the final cutscene and credits.
In the end, it was time to fill the world with narrative. We were all pretty sure of the direction we wanted this to go, but the execution was another matter.

A handful of murals were going to explain the major plot points, and when I got rigged petrified stone people from the art team, I gleefully began placing them all over the world to tell stories of the various stages of civilization's decline.

pageContent.description: stone people as storrytelling vehicles
concept for our loops and verbs developed by the design team

pageContent.content: The proccess and team management learnings

content: At the beginning, the challenge was to create an environment where everyone could help shape the game with their ideas, while making sure we were all aiming for a coherent experience. It was important for us to distribute the responsibility for decisions among everyone involved in the potential execution.
In my role as Lead Designer, I envisioned the design process as taking feedback from other departments as well as other members of the design team to ensure alignment.

On the one hand, I worked closely with the producer to define time limits and sprint goals; on the other hand, I tried to be a reflector for the other designers, working with them to analyze and elaborate on their design concepts.

We discovered pretty early on that because of our different personalities and strong opinions, even on topics that turned out to be completely irrelevant, we had to spend hours discussing various issues related to the future game we wanted to develop.

pageContent.description: some internal planning and feedback for design

content: The team was split between the goal of developing a playable version as early as possible and the goal of making the best decisions now to end up developing on best concept later.
I felt that not enough attention was paid to design, while we were talking about artistic decisions and narrative inspiration way too early, especially considering the development time of two months.

We were constantly adapting our processes to the new team dynamics and the problems that the previous process caused. One of the changes that stuck almost to the end was the introduction of feature pairs.
Two people from different departments working together on a feature proved effective in tackling game-defining changes without requiring discussions with the entire team.

One of the dynamics of moving closer to deadlines and milestones was a clearer understanding that the short sprint period needed to be used to create something that would move the game forward, as too many discussions about 'woulds' and 'coulds' carried the real risk of ending up with an unfinished project.

pageContent.description: example on how proposals were visualized and planned with for finishing the game

content: In the end, we found a fairly productive process of proposing changes, naming the effort, and the team volunteering to decide which proposals to work on.
Anyone could suggest something, but not nearly everyone did.
It's hard to say if this process would have worked in the beginning, but it certainly worked very well for the final process.

hkw.name: Spiel das HKW
description: As part of a project for the HKW we created several prototypes and polished one of them for an exhibition we also prepared.

content: This was a cooperation project with the HKW, one of the most important cultural institutions in berlin.
The goal was to analyze their workflows and processes in an artistic way. With a small team of four, we used the media of games to attend the ‘Introspection’.

During the process we created four prototypes, a card game and polished a final game, as well as prepared the exhibition, processed our material and constructed an arcade Machine to present our final game in the best way possible.
Game Design
Prototyping
Exhibition preparation
Interviews
Arcade Machine construction

pageContent.description: Opening the exhibition

content: In addition to interviews we conducted with various HKW employees, we decided that the best way to get to know them was to develop prototypes and see how they reacted while playing.
For the prototypes, we tried to be as diverse as possible, taking into account different genres, platforms, and audiences.
We started by developing a simple adventure game that focused heavily on representing physical space and told an authentic story from our perspective at HKW.
It was meant to serve as an introduction and included a message to approach us for an interview or playtest of future prototypes.
We decided to go with a story-focused adventure, as that was the most accessible thing we could think of.
The next prototype was a platformer about a fox who works at HKW and goes home to his family in the Tiergarten.

It still had a low barrier to entry, no hard jumps or death conditions, but it included some small toy-like simulations and much more focus on the user experience, as polish was something that helped our playtesters a lot. The toys, however, were not something our audience appreciated.
Next on our list was a Tycoon game, which is about organizing events like those that are common at HKW.
We created a little simulation peppered with lots of little jokes about hkw's problems, which seemed to go over well with the staff.
It especially helped us eliminate more 3D games from the list of possibilities.

pageContent.description: Playing the card-game with the employess

content: The last direction we wanted to try was a card game.
The people working there really lacked opportunities for face-to-face interaction between departments.
We developed and discussed social mechanisms like collecting and trading cards with other players.
Individual goals and the freedom of how trading should work opened up the space for conversations.
Ultimately, though, the final product had to be a digital game, and we settled on a simple platformer with a linear story and lots of jokes about the hkw themselves.
Visually, the game included key features of the real hkw buildings.
To get the most out of the concept, we decided to build our own arcade machine to showcase it.
The exhibition featured all the prototypes, the finished game on the machine, and a large flowchart we had created from the interviews of how the things that engaged the staff related to each other.

watson.name: A Case for Watson
description: A first person narrative driven detective game. Play doctor Watson, getting the opportunity to solve a crime on his own, without the help of his genius partner: Sherlock Holmes.

content: A Case for Watson is a first person narrative driven detective game.
The player takes the role of the famous doctor Watson, who ends up having the opportunity to solve a crime on his own, without the help of his genius partner: Sherlock Holmes.
Save important answers, take drawings of the environment and then walk your way through the crime by confronting the characters with the evidences you've collected.

cw.name: Corona World
description: Shortly after the lockdown started, the people from browser ballet reached out to me with the idea to make a game about Covid19.

content: Shortly after the lockdown started, the people from browser ballet reached out to me with the idea to make a game about Covid19.
Of course the game had to be done quickly so the topic was contemporary and new, so I gathered together a small team.
Creative Direction & Project Lead
2D Graphic Design
Environmental Design
The girls and guys from the browser ballet team are known for their satiric content so the game had to fit their special kind of humor as well.
They already brought a simple concept to the table which helped us to base all our design on it.
We had the freedom to add a lot of our own ideas which we considered suitable and which ensured to make the game a coherent experience.
I spend a lot of time on the project overseeing the general direction but also had to put in a lot of work in the visual style.
Since I'm not that experienced in creating new art styles for games, I had to invest some time in understanding and developing our the visual language of the game.
The final style lives on a small brink between communicating interactivity as well as importance and presenting the general mood they wished for.
